trial_identification.studytitle: Quantifying the effect of nitrous oxide on the depth of anaesthesia using theoretically based time series modelling
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effect of nitrous oxide on a new measure of anaesthetic depth during sevoflurane anaesthesia

interventions.interventions: Patient randomised to 0% (control), 33% or 66% nitrous oxide during induction of anaethesia with sevoflurane.
interventions.comparator: 0% (control) nitrous oxide during induction of anaethesia with sevoflurane.

primaryOutcome.outcome: The effect of nitrous oxide on the EEG during induction of anaesthesia with sevoflurane
primaryOutcome.timepoint: The EEG is recorded continuously from the commencement of sevoflurane administration until loss of response to painful stimulation.

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: No secondary outcome - no timepoint for secondary outcome.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Presenting for surgery, not at risk of gastrointestinal reflux during anaeshtesia, and without epilepsy or other EEG adnormalities.

trial_design.sequence: Randomisation using computer generated random number list. No blocking or stratification

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Royal Melbourne Hospital Grattan St Parkville Victoria 3050

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The purpose of this study is to determine the effects of nitrous oxide on the EEG, by randomising patients to inhaled induction of anaesthesia using nitrous oxide 33% or 66% or 0% with sevoflurane
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Liley DT, LESLIE K, Sinclair NC, Feckie M. Dissociating the effects of nitrous oxide on brain electrical activity using fixed order time series modeling. Computers in Biology and Medicine 2008: 38:1121-30
